topic.title: HP Helion 1.2 Development Platform: Using the cloud-init Package

body.p: cloud-init (the Ubuntu package for handling early initialization of cloud instances) can be used to provide additional flexibility when configuring Application Lifecycle Service cluster nodes, and can simplify joining a cluster and assigning roles.
cloud-init can be configured at instance launch time by pasting YAML directly into the Openstack Horizon interface.
For example, given a core node at IP 10.2.3.4, the following cloud-config would add a new DEA node to the cluster:

ul.li: nats:ip will run kato attach <nats ip> the first time the VM is booted.
extname when supplied with a fully qualified domain name will run kato rename <extname> on the instance first boot.
Roles takes a list of roles to configure the node with.

section.title: Securing the new node
section.p: To lock down and secure this new node, you could use standard cloud-config directives for adding any SSH keys, randomizing passwords, and/or disabling password based authentication entirely. An example that creates a data services node, enables passwordless sudo for the admin group, and disables password based authentication:

codeblock.codeph:
#cloud-config
helion: nats: ip: 10.2.3.4 roles: ['data-services']
chpasswd: list: | helion:RANDOM root:RANDOM ubuntu:RANDOM expire: false ssh_pwauth: false
bootcmd: - - cloud-init-per - once - sudo_admin_group_nopasswd - sed - -ri - s|^%admin .*|%admin ALL=\(ALL\) NOPASSWD:ALL| - /etc/sudoers

section.title: Custom System Configuration
section.p: In addition to the Application Lifecycle Service node configuration tasks described above, cloud-init can be used for a variety of system setup tasks:

ul.li: setting up chef, puppet, salt-stack, or MCollective
setting the locale and time zone
resizing the root filesystem to take up all available space, making it easy to grow a snapshot

section.p: For more information on cloud-init, refer to the official CloudInit documentation.
